context.description: This dialog allows you to create and configure a new Azure Deployment Project for deploying your Java applications, runtime and server to the Azure cloud.
This dialog allows you to configure a Azure role.
This dialog allows you to edit the properties of your Azure Deployment Project.
This dialog allows you to configure remote access for all the roles in your project at the same time.

topic.label: Enabling Remote Access in Azure Using Eclipse

context.description:
This dialog allows you to create a new self-signed X.509 certificate that you can use for testing purposes in scenarios involving encryption or digital signing.
Two files will be generated: a certificate file with the public key only (*.CER), and a file containing both the private and the public key (*.PFX).
This dialog allows you to register an existing Azure storage account in the list of storage accounts known to Eclipse.

This dialog enables you to automatically create remote debug configurations for your applications deployed to Azure:
1. Select the project containing the Java code that you wish to debug
2. Specify the types of debug configurations to create (emulator and/or cloud)
If creating a cloud configuration, you need to upload your deployment to Azure first, to obtain the host address assigned to your deployment. Then enter it here.
When done, you will see the new debug configuration(s) created for your workspace under the “Remote Java Application” category.
Note: Encryption support for debugging connections is not enabled yet, therefore using remote debugging for applications deployed to the public cloud is discouraged.
This dialog enables you to configure co-located caching on a Azure Role.
This dialog enables you to manage your certificates.
This dialog enables you to configure a named cache.

This dialog allows you to configure the selected Azure role to accept remote debugging connections for your Java application and to automatically create the relevant debug configurations for the emulator and the cloud.
This dialog allows you to configure the fire wall and port routing settings for your deployment, by enabling specific service end points.
This dialog allows you to specify the environment variables that you want to be set at the time the startup task for the selected Azure role is executed.

This dialog allows you to configure temporary named local storage resources of the desired size in the virtual machine where your application will be run, and to save their automatically determined directory paths in environment variables that will be available when this role's startup task is executed.
This dialog allows you to enable HTTP session affinity (“sticky sessions”) for this Azure role, for the selected input end point.
This dialog allows you to enable SSL offloading (HTTPS) for your Azure cloud service.
This dialog enables you to describe how to import and deploy a component into the selected Azure role.
This dialog enables you to specify the JDK, the server and the applications to include in your deployment.
This dialog enables you to specify components to import into and deploy with your deployment, as well as command lines to run at startup.
This dialog allows you to add a Java application to your server deployment.

context.title: Publish to Azure from Eclipse
context.description: This dialog allows you to publish your deployment to the Azure cloud.

context.title: Create a New Cloud Service
context.description: This dialog allows you to create a new cloud service for your deployment.

context.title: Create a New Storage Account
context.description: This dialog allows you to create a new storage account needed for uploading your deployment to the Azure cloud.

context.title: Unpublish a Deployment from Azure Cloud
context.description: This dialog allows you to remove a previously published deployment from the Azure cloud.

context.title: Credentials Configurations
context.description: This dialog allows you to manage the credentials for your Azure subscriptions.
